subject: Re: [junit] testing private methods in Struts Actions ?
msgSnippet: ... What do you want to test here? 1. How well your business logic integrates with Struts (reading form beans, populating error messages, that kind of thing..)
messageBody:
frank zou wrote:

> The issues really confused me. Testing gurus, please give me a hand.
> Thanks.

What do you want to test here?

1. How well your business logic integrates with Struts (reading form
beans, populating error messages, that kind of thing..)

or

2. Your business logic itself

Either way, putting the business logic directly into the Struts Action
creates a problem; therefore, create a separate class for your business
logic and have the Struts Action invoke it. It looks somethign like this:

public ActionForward execute(ActionMapping mapping, ActionForm form,
HttpServletRequest request,
HttpServletResponse response)
{

createEventLog(request);

handleSessionAndToken(request);

doBusinessLogic(new BusinessLogicImpl(...));
...
clearUserRelatedCookies(siteId, response);

String returnUrl = createReturnUrl(mapping, request);
request.setAttribute(LOGIN_RETURN_URL, returnUrl);
return mapping.findForward(PAGE_SUCCESS);
}

public void doBusinessLogic(BusinessLogic logic) {
logic.execute();
}

Now the interface BusinessLogic represents your transaction script. The
implementation BusinessLogicImpl does the production work. You can test
the business logic on its own by instantiating whatever you need: action
form objects, request objects, whatever. You can test the integration
with Struts by faking/mocking the business logic (Google "jmock").

The entire technique probably requires 10 pages to describe with
examples, so I won't be doing that here. :)

Good luck.
